The Gene Designer Menu

Menu Options

Window

Default options for controlling positioning of window, including minimization. Shortcut for minimization on OS X is Cmd-M.

File

Undo
Restores value of currently selected text box to a previous state. Works for Sequence, Vector, and Amino Acid Sequence text boxes. Shortcut: Cmd-Z.
Redo
Undo an undo. Shortcut: Cmd-Y.
About
Find out more about Gene Designer.
Quit
Exit the program. Shortcut: Cmd-Q.

Reference

Enzyme Reference
Opens a window displaying a list of restriction enzymes and the target pattern at which they cut. Consult the REBASE database for where the enzyme cuts in relation to the sequence. Click the thumbnail for an image:
Codon Reference
Opens a window displaying a list of codons and their associated amino acid translations. Click the thumbnail for an image:
Commercial Reference
Opens a window with a table enzymes and vendors according to the REBASE database. A legend associating each vendor with a letter is located at the top of the window. Click the thumbnail for an image:

Databases

Restriction Enzymes--up to date as of 10/6/10
Add Restriction Enzyme--creates a panel for you to enter the enzyme name, the pattern the enzyme recognizes, methylation sites, and commercial suppliers. Information should be entered as done in the REBASE databases: http://rebase.neb.com/rebase
Delete Restriction Enzyme--deletes the restriction enzyme currently selected in the enzyme list. This is a permanent change! If an enzyme is accidentally deleted, you can re-enter the information through the "Add Restriction Enzyme" option.
Vectors
Add Vector--creates a panel for the addition of a vector to the database. Enter the vector name and vector sequence in the boxes provided. Alternatively, a vector may be added from a file in FASTA format.
Delete Vector--deletes the vector currently selected in the vector list
Codon Usage
Add Organism--creates a panel where you may enter an organism name and a nucleotide sequence. Gene Designer will compute the frequency of each codon in the sequence and store it in the database. You may also enter codon frequency percentages (out of 1000) if known.
Delete Organism--deletes the currently selected organism in the menu below. This is a permanent change! E. coli K-12 is not allowed to be deleted.
Submenu--list of organisms whose codon frequencies can be used by Gene Designer in optimizing sequences or in making mutations to sequences. E. coli K-12 is the default but other organisms can be added through the add organism option.
Templates
Template Sequence Database--displays a list of all sequences already added to the template database. Clicking the load sequence button loads the currently highlighted sequence into the Mutation Panel and Optimization Panel displays. Click the thumbnail for an image:
Add New Template Sequences--User selects a FASTA file containing sequences. The user is allowed to rename sequences before submission to the database. Sequences are stored permanently to make it easy to looad for future use.

Tools

Check Sequence/Host Toxicity
Reports whether any codons in the sequence entered into the sequence box represent less than 1% of the total codons of the "host" organism. The host organism is the selected organism on the "Codon Usage" submenu found under the databases menu. By default E. coli K-12 is the selected host. Shortcut: Cmd-T
Find Open Reading Frame
Finds open reading frames (ORFs) of a minimum length (determined by the number of amino acids between the start and stop codons) specified by the user in a pop-up dialog. The start and end positions of all ORFs meeting the criteria are displayed along with the ORF nucleotide sequence. A pop-up will inform the user if no ORFs satisfy the requirements.
Homology Modeling
User selects a FASTA file containing protein sequences with template sequence listed first. The PDB file for the template sequence should be in the same directory as the FASTA file. An alignment of the sequences is created and Modeller is used to create a homology model. The resulting model is displayed using PyMol.
